transcripts.text: hey everybody how you doing?  i'm dr boyce walkins from intelligent boss moves and i'm here with What right now might be the craziest man in the world for what he's trying to do, Mr.  Damon Dash.  How you doing, brother?  What's happening?
How you doing?

Doing good, man.  Doing good.  Now, the reason I say this is that right now you're trying to do what some people think is the impossible.  You are actually trying to defy Hollywood and work outside of Hollywood and create a major, major film, too honorable, and you're doing it with your own money.  What's that been like for you?

I mean, I'm kind of used to putting up my own money, you know, for anything I've ever wanted to do.  If I have an idea and I present it to other people, it's kind of hard for them to believe in it and for them to move when I want to move.  And if it's my dream for it to remain my dream.  So I've always initially put up my own bread down from Rachel Roy.  It was millions.  And to Rockefeller, we put up our own bread there until we got the co-venture.  And to now, making movies.  just, you know, based on my experience, the only way I could make a good movie is to do it myself.  So, yeah, I put up the bread to make it.  I directed it, produced it.  We're going to self-distribute it, you know, unless somebody comes in and helps us out with that.  You know, but it's been all right.  I'm not mad at it.  You know, the thing about being an independent is when you put out your own money... In that moment, you might feel like you broke, but you know you're not because you got work on the street.  But, you know, what my belief is, you know, being broke is pregame for being rich.  You understand what I'm saying?  You have to be broke because, again, if there's any demand, you have to supply it, you have to pay for it.  So in independent business, the bigger you get, the broker you're going to be.  You understand what I'm saying?  But as long as you have that cash flow, it's all right.  So I'm cool with it, you know, because it's nothing I'm not used to.  And also we've had to build the platform, Dame Dash Studios, to showcase all the films that I'm making independently.  So not only are we making the movie, we're also making the platform to showcase the movie where you can get it for $10 a month or $50 for the whole year.  But again, being out of pocket about a million dollars, it doesn't feel the most comfortable, but it's the most comfortable.  You understand what I'm saying?  It's like you have to have both.  You have to be uncomfortable to be comfortable.  So it just goes with it.  I'm the kind of guy that's like proud when I'm broke.  You understand what I'm saying?  I'm like, yo, I'm broke.  You know why?  Because I got a lot of work on the street.  And to someone intelligent, that's not considered broke.  But to some dumbass, yeah, I'm broke.  I got a million dollars on the street.  Once I collect it, it comes back to five million, but I'll consider that broke.  You know what I mean?  And I don't have no money to lend you, by the way.  You understand what I'm saying?  So that's the way I'm at, and that's where I'm at with it.

Wow, wow.  So, you know, we know that being a boss sort of has that double-edged aspect to it, right?  I mean, you got the time when you're up, the time when you bet it all and it doesn't work out.  How do you come back from that when something you do doesn't work out the way you want it to?

That's about timing to me.  If it doesn't work out the way I want it to now, then it means come back and work it out until it's where I want it to be.  So I never consider anything a loss.  It's always a learning experience.  It's only a loss when it breaks you to the extent that you quit.  But usually, when it looks like a loss, it's the opportunity to make it a way bigger win.  Just because it's not the way you want to do it and it doesn't happen when you want it to happen, it doesn't make it wrong.  You understand what I'm saying?  Basically, it means that you just were maybe wrong about your calculation of when you were gonna get your money back or how you were gonna get your money back.  Part of winning is losing.  You understand what I'm saying?  You got to do it wrong to do it right.  How else are you gonna know unless you just step in shit?  And that barely ever happens.  So when you're doing something for the first time, it's rare you're ever going to do it right.  It's rare.  it's not going to be costly, but it's also rare that I would ever quit and take it as a loss.  So I don't consider, I don't do losses.  I just keep working until I win.  So if I'm in a fight and I get punched, it doesn't mean I lost.  If I get knocked out, I'm getting back up, but I'm swinging harder.  But as long as I can get up, I'm going to keep fighting.

We know you're iconic for your generation.  I think that people observe your attitude.  It's just sort of this, you talk about lifestyle and I think that's part of it, but it's also spirit.  You have a certain kind of spirit that people identify with to the point where if you were gone tomorrow, people will probably be talking about you 20 years from now.  Another person who had a similar type of spirit was actually Tupac Shakur.  Now, I'm curious.  I never asked you this.  Did you ever run across or, like, cross paths with Pac?

I mean, you know, I was in the game when hip-hop, I was talking to Jay Gunnar about this, was a whole completely different monster of competitiveness.  There was Nas, there was Biggie, there was Pac.  You know, it was, you know, all these different artists that went to Wu-Tang at one time being competitive.  So I was there a lot for, like, I was there when Biggie and Pac were in the club in  L.A.,  and J.O.  Fellini was performing.  Like, I was there for that.  As far as him and I having any personal business together, not really.  And, you know, basically around the time that, you know, he did pass was around the time where it was that division of East and West, which I didn't really love.  I thought that that was a... I didn't love that game at all.
Definitely bad for business.
Bad for business, but bad for culture.  Just, you know, beefing in general for no reason when you should be getting money.  You know, that doesn't ever make any sense to me.
Or maybe it was good for business for the people that were selling magazines, building the beef, right?

You know what I could say?  Whoever was the record company executive at that time was supposed to sit whatever beefs, whoever he had a beef with, sit them down.  and maybe it was Jimmy Iovine, whoever it was, I'm not sure if it was Interscope, and make them squash it.  You know, like, when I had an artist that had a problem with an artist that I knew, they would have to get in a room, and we wasn't leaving until it was squashed, and I wasn't getting no more money with you until it was squashed.  I never, like, chose a side.  It was always about peace.  So, for me, in hip-hop, it was always about squashing beef.  I paused.  I squashed way more beef than anyone could ever even imagine.  You know what I'm saying?  It was always some kind of a competitive thing.  amongst the different crews.  And the crews were real.  We were authentic.  We were all from the same extreme circumstance.  So I knew what could happen if they went any further.  It would be dumbness.  And what happens when you're famous and influential and you do something foolish, a lot of people do something foolish.  So it's always important for us to do something smart, especially when we're at that platform where we're influencing other people.  So my point is, back in that day, I wish I could have got closer to him so I could have been able to understand his perspective a little better and talk him through whatever was going on and see what it was about.  But I never was really with Pac like that.  You know, we never really got so cool.
And you were both young at the time.  I mean, he was, what, 24 or something like that.  So you're about the same age as Pac, right?
I guess.

I'm 44 now.  Yeah, I think that if he was still alive, he'd be the same age as you and I, because I remember when he died, my best friend got murdered around the same time, and we were all like the same age, you know?  So it seems like it would have been tough as a 24-year-old.  But the reason I think about this is because now we're looking at it from the perspective of 44-year-olds, And you look back and you see the role that the media played in this, right?  You know, putting people on magazine covers, kind of building things up.  And then it gets to the point where they're making money, but they don't have necessarily, how can I say this?  Because I want to link this to your culture vultures conversation.  They don't have a stake in the people that are affected, right?
They don't have a conscious.
There you go.

You know, it's like out of sight, out of mind.  You don't see who it affects, you know, except your pockets.  You know, and you consider a win, you make it money, but if somebody dies, that's not a loss to you because you don't know them.  You understand what I'm saying?  So that's why you, on a social level, you always have to be conscious of what you promote and what you make money off of, especially when there's other people in problems.  But problems make money no matter what, from my, you know, experience.  You know, no matter what.  I think, you know, me in the newspaper and in the press, um... You know, there was a time I was paying two, three publicists at a time.  And like I told you before, for $10,000, you could be the most famous person in the world.  $10,000 in publicists, you could be anywhere you want to be at any time.  But once you stop paying for it and, you know, the magazines or the platforms that are showcasing, you see that you get readers or you get the certain attention, they're going to put you in the newspaper any like they can, whether it's negative or positive.  Either way, it's going to sell.  Usually negative sells more than positive.
Okay, so that's kind of the tough part for you as well, right?  I don't give a fuck.  You don't give a fuck?  I don't.  So don't care at all?

Do I act like I care?  If I cared, my actions reflect my amount of caring for other people's opinions.  All I care about is my close circle of people that I respect and myself and my family.  And as long as what I'm doing is good for them, I could care less what anybody thinks.  So if someone wants to monetize gossip or foolishness or things that aren't true because they have no understanding of it, go ahead.  But it doesn't mean I'm gonna be effective.  I mean, I literally know people that are at that famous level and are in the paper every day that would cry or their day was affected by.  however they were portrayed that day in the newspaper.  And I always thought that was ridiculous.  It's like, you sign on to that.  You already know that they're gonna come at you, whether it's true or it's not true.  People are gonna talk about you, whether it's true or not true.  Sometimes you have your good days, sometimes you have your bad days.  At the end of the day, do your kids, can they afford a nanny?  Can they afford to go to private school?  Can they afford to go on vacation?  And are you spending the right amount of time with them?  That's your wealth.  Other than that, everything else is irrelevant.

So if you were to pick out some things that you think, just maybe one thing that the public thinks about Dame Dash that is not true, that's not consistent with reality.  What area would you say that you most misunderstood?

You know, I don't know, because I don't really know what people think about me.  You know what I'm saying?  Because I hear a lot of people call me an asshole, but I'm still here.  Everybody, you know what I'm saying?  It's like, usually you want the asshole out of here.  You stop talking about him.  You know what I'm saying?  So I'm not going to say I'm not an asshole because I am.  I am to people that deserve it.  You know, if you're not the right kind of person and you're not doing things correct, I want you to hate me because I'm going to fucking make you suffer.  verbally, mentally, not physically, but within the law and within respect, I'm gonna make you feel exactly what you are.  I will be that asshole if you're not doing right by, you know, culture, just playing the game correct.  I'm not gonna be the nicest guy.  You understand what I'm saying?  But what I do see that people don't mention the most is that I'm a full-time dad.  You understand that, you know, I took care of my son, Boogie, since he was eight as a single father.  No one talks about the fight that I have to be a dad, which is the most important wealth of them all.  That's where you have to be rich.  You could have as much money in the bank, you could have many companies, you could be having cars, girls, and all that.  If you got kids, and your kids aren't happy, and you're not taking care of them, you're broke, and you're a hurt.  You understand?  So I don't understand why they never talk about that.  This kid, me, fought, went through a trial to get my child, Boogs, just so that I could be that dad for him and make sure that he gets a well-rounded childhood and become a great adult and prepare him to be a man.  I did that on my own.  I went to court.  While I was in court, your man Charlemagne and your man Wendy Williams, they shitted on me the whole time.  They bombed on me the whole time.  Every time there was something said about me in court, regardless of whether it was ridiculous or not, they were the main ones talking about it all the time.  But despite the fact that I got custody of him, that never got reported.  The fact that I've been a parent all this time, that never got reported.  And that's the part that I don't respect, because that's the most important thing of them all.  How come they're not talking about the parent that I am and the fight and the struggle that I have always to be a parent?  I'm always fighting to raise my children, and that's the fight I'll never stop.

So do you think that for black men that are in prominent positions like yourself, that there is kind of this leaning toward pointing out areas that might be perceived as being irresponsible as opposed to...

I think as far as being an independent man that's against the system, they're going to look for anything to make you look irresponsible.  And they're going to focus on the negative and never the positive.  But the real positive, like I said, the real wealth, no one's talking about that.  You don't hear about a person being a parent, but you definitely hear about somebody being laid on a bill.
Mm, okay.  So what about Two Honorable?  What are your predictions for your film?

I mean, you know, I think it's gonna definitely set the stage for me to make other films because of the quality of it, me as a director, as a filmmaker.  See, that's another thing.  There's an expectation of me to be good at everything.  Like, I'm supposed to have more than one.  Like, Rachel Roy makes, not to talk to business, but it's a $50 million company at least on a bad day.  And unless I have five other companies that are doing that, I'm doing bad.  I can't just have one.  Mm.  You know, I have to have 10.  You know what I mean?  So as a mogul or in hip-hop, if you have only one company that's rolling, rolling, then you're not doing good, or at least if it's me, especially if you're an independent.  I guess if someone gives you a job and you have a great salary and you have one job, one great salary, and you're working for somebody, they give you all the praise in the world.  They make a person look like they're wealthier than they are.  What people don't understand is, to me, rich... is temporary.  But wealth is being able to have your children and grandchildren spend the money that you made and also be able to sustain.  Where generations can eat off the labor or the fruit of your labor.  That's wealth to me.  So at this point, it's not even about the immediate money or the car or whatever it is or the jury.  It's about how good my kids are doing.  It's about how good their kids are gonna do.  It's about the house you live in.  It's about the things that you can pass to your children and your children.  And that's what wealth is to me and that's what I'm trying to aggregate.  That's what I'm trying to put together.  I've been rich.  I can make quick money and I can spend quick money and I can loan out quick money that I'll never get back or get robbed for quick money.  You understand what I'm saying?  Or put a jury on my neck for quick money.  But how many people got businesses?  How many people got bricks?  Meaning houses and art and things that other people besides yourself can enjoy.  Being wealthy means looking out for other people before you look out for yourself.  So as long as my kids go to private school, you know, I'm wealthy.  But if I'm rich and I got a car, I can't afford to put my kid in school, I'm broke.  It makes no sense.  And how much of that goes on?  But then they're going to put you in the newspaper and say that you're rolling just because, you know, you have something that aesthetically you can see, but the stuff that really counts, nobody shows.

Okay, everybody.  So the lesson for today that I think you want to understand is that there's a difference between being rich and being wealthy.  And also make sure you understand that the climb to the top is always tough.  You know, when you talk about having freedom, there's a price to be paid for freedom.  If you're not willing to pay the price, then you probably won't get it.  All right.
Can't be afraid to be broke.  if you want to be rich.
Bingo.  There you go.  Or wealthy.  Hey everybody, I'm Dr.  Boyce Watkins from Intelligent Boss Moves and this is my friend Mr.  Damon Dash.  How you doing today, brother?  I'm good.
How you doing?
Doing good, man.
Working hard today.

Trying to, man.  You know, trying to.  You know, brother get a job.  But then again, we don't really get jobs.  We own jobs.  Yeah, we get jobs.  So this is my job.  I'm giving to myself because we believe in that boss mentality and I think that that's important in terms of promoting that lifestyle.  Now my question is this.
A lot.
